member.summary: Day of week of the interval.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.RateScheduleInterval.Start
member.summary: Interval's start point offset relative to start of a day or a service depending on .
member.remarks: For valid values range is [0h; 24h), which means all the day () excluding it's right bound. For valid values range is [0h; 12h), because max service duration is 12h.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.RateScheduleInterval.End
member.summary: Interval's end point offset relative to start of a day or a service depending on .
member.remarks: For valid values range is (0h; 24h], which means all the day () exluding it's left bound. For valid values range is (0h; 12h], because max service duration is 12h. Anyway, is greater than , so that interval has positive length.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.RateSchedule
member.summary: A schedule of a service rates.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.RateSchedule.TimingMode
member.summary: Time rate calculation mode, which specifies how to treat rate schedule interval bounds.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.RateSchedule.MinimumDuration
member.summary: Minumum duration of a service or null if there is no lower limit. If the lower limit is set and the actual duration is below of limit, it will be rounded up.

list.item: Actual service duration is 15 minutes, is 10 minutes and is not set: service duration will just be rounded up to a multiple of , the result is 20 minutes.

Actual service duration is 15 minutes, is 10 minutes and is 1 hour: at first service duration will be rounded up to 1 hour to meet the and then will be rounded up to a multiple of , the result is 1 hour.
Actual service duration is 75 minutes, is 10 minutes and is 1 hour: 75 mins already meets the , so it will only be rounded up to a multiple of , the result is 1 hour 20 mins.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.RateSchedule.TimingStep
member.summary: Length of the service duration increment steps. Actual service duration is always rounded up to a multiple of this value.

list.item: Actual service duration is 15 minutes, is 10 minutes and is not set: service duration will just be rounded up to a multiple of , the result is 20 minutes.

Actual service duration is 15 minutes, is 10 minutes and is 1 hour: at first service duration will be rounded up to 1 hour to meet the and then will be rounded up to a multiple of , the result is 1 hour.
Actual service duration is 75 minutes, is 10 minutes and is 1 hour: 75 mins already meets the , so it will only be rounded up to a multiple of , the result is 1 hour 20 mins.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.RateSchedule.Items
member.summary: List of non-default rates. Each item is a set of non-intersecting time intervals having own price. All time intervals that are not covered by any of the schedule items have a default price.
member.remarks: Time intervals pricing difference is implemented via binding to different products (). Order item of a service type () has a primary service product () and additional rate products ( ), which are specified by the rates schedule ().

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the .

member.summary: Time rate calculation modes, which specifies how to treat rate schedule interval bounds.

member.name: F:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.ServiceTimingMode.DayTime
member.summary: Rate schedule interval bounds are relative to a day start. Allows to have different rates for different times of a day, e.g. reduced price for morning hours and advanced price for evening hours, which helps to keep balance between prime time and unpopular periods of a day.

member.name: F:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.ServiceTimingMode.ServiceTime
member.summary: Rate schedule interval bounds are relative to a service start. It allows to have different rates for different service hours, e.g. full price for the first hour of the service, 90% price for the second hour and so on, which motivates to increase service duration.

member.summary: The service menu item. Expected to be of type .

member.summary: Default price of the service. Some periods may have own prices, see . All prices are per timing step ().

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItem.Cost
member.summary: Total cost of the service item, sum of costs of the plus .

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItem.RemainingLimitCost
member.summary: Predicted cost of the remaining time limit. Zero, if the is not set. If the time limit is set, but it's less than total time of the , remaining time limit is zero and therefore it's cost is also zero. For example, if timing step is one minute, the time limit was set to 1 hour and 20 minutes already passed, there will be one or more periods with total time of 20 minutes and their respective costs, then the cost of remaining 40 minutes will be predicted using schedule. This cost will go down with the lapse of time, because while time of some period increases, the remaining time limit decreases. After 15 minutes total periods time will be 35 mins (20+15) and will represent cost of the remaining 25 mins.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItem.ResultSum
member.summary: Total sum to be paid, sum with discounts and both included and excluded vat.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItem.TaxPercent
member.summary: Tax percent or null for not taxed order items.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItem.TimeLimit
member.summary: Total amount of time after which the service will be stopped or null for default limit (12 hours). Includes all periods.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItem.IsStarted
member.summary: Whether the service is running now.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItem.RateSchedule
member.summary: Schedule of the service rates.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItem.Periods
member.summary: Service periods, each period represents some rate. For example, if the schedule has different rates for times before and after 10 o'clock, the service was started at 09:30 and now is 11:00, there will be one period with 30 mins length and another period with 60 mins length, both periods may have different prices and therefore different costs.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItemPeriod
member.summary: Period of a service item.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItemPeriod.Service
member.summary: Product that specifies price of the period. Expected to be of types or .

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItemPeriod.Price
member.summary: Price of the service period per timing step ().

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItemPeriod.Cost
member.summary: Cost of the service period.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderServiceItemPeriod.ElapsedTime
member.summary: Exact total elapsed time of the period, includes all runs of the period. Service may be started, then stopped, then started again, or the schedule may switch the service to another rate and then switch back, so this property will accumulate total active time of the period. This is exact unrounded value. For example, if timing step is 10 mins and this period was active only for 2 mins and 42 seconds, the will be calculated for 10 mins anyway, while this property will have an exact value 00:02:42.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderModifierItem.IsSeparate
member.summary: Whether modifier should be cooked separately from its product. In general this property exposes modifier semantics: while some modifiers specify how to cook their product, another modifiers are additional dish parts or even separate dishes. First type completely depends on product and has the same cooking property values, second type is separate and has own kitchen, status etc.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrderModifierItem.AmountIndependentOfParentAmount
member.summary: Whether amount of the modifier is absolute or relative to parent amount. When modifier amount depends on parent, it means multiplication specified amount of modifier should be cooked per each parent unit, otherwise it means addition specified amount of modifier should be cooked for whole parent.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IDiscountItem
member.summary: Discount item is the result of adding discount to an order, contains discount parameters, which will be used to calculate sums. While discount params are persistent, discount sums are calculated on demand, because they are subject to change (they may depend on the time, etc). Call to get calculated sums.

member.summary: Gets estimated guests count, that is greater than or equal to added guests count. When single order is used to serve many people and handling each of them as a separate guest may be inconvenient, this property will indicate estimated guests count while guests collection will contain as many guests as needed for waiters.

member.summary: Optional marker used to specify order origin. This property contains either null or name of the source order was received from. Specifying origin allows to analyse efficiency of external order sources such as different web-sites, mobile applications and so on.

member.summary: Whether order was prepaid. Any processed or deleted prepay.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrder.IsTopCookingPriority
member.summary: The flag specifies that this order should be cooked out-of-order at kitchen. All orders which have this flag set on will appear above other orders at the kitchen display. Both groups (top priority and non-top priority) will be sorted separately using usual sorting logic (custom cooking priority, then default built-in criterions. Default value is false.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Orders.IOrder.CookingPriority
member.summary: Specifies a custom cooking priority. While the application provides built-in prioritization logic for orders based on timing, dish courses, etc., you can override it and enforce custom cooking order based on your external logic. Ideally, all dishes should be cooked timely, but in case of concurrency when kitchen is high-loaded, you have to decide which orders are more important and should be cooked in the first place and which orders are allowed to be delayed. Higher priority values mean that the order, its serve groups and dishes will appear at the kitchen display earlier. Default value is zero. Both positive and negative values are allowed for raising and lowering the priority correspondingly. Orders with the same cooking priority will be sorted using default built-in logic.

member.summary: Specifies how to select printer to print a section-related document on a specific terminal.
member.remarks: Each has printer settings and each terminal (iikoFront application instance) also may have it's own printer settings, so it's necessary to specify, which settings to use to select a printer.

member.name: F:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Print.PrinterSelectionMode.Default
member.summary: Treat section settings as a base level and terminal settings as an override. Printer will be selected by terminal settings if they specify some printer for a document, otherwise printer will be selected using section settings.

member.summary: Select printer using section settings. Terminal settings will be ignored.

member.name: F:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Print.PrinterSelectionMode.ByTerminal
member.summary: Select printer using terminal settings. Currently, section settings will be used as a fallback if printer cannot be selected by terminal, so this option coincides with , but it's just an implementation detail, which may be changed at any time.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Assortment.ITemplatedModifierParams
member.summary: Product-specific settings of the compound item template modifier. describes general modifier settings for all products of that template, different products may specify different default amount and free of charge amount for each group modifier, child modifier or simple modifier. If is null, this instance is about simple modifier, otherwise this instance describes params for group modifier, then says whether it's about group itself or about child of that group.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.KitchenOrderItemProcessingStatus
member.summary: Describes order item processing lifecycle from kitchen point of view.

member.name: F:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.KitchenOrderItemProcessingStatus.Idle
member.summary: Order item was printed, but cooking didn't start yet.

member.name: F:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.KitchenOrderItemProcessingStatus.Processing1
member.summary: Order item cooking was started, cooking is in first step progress.

member.name: F:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.KitchenOrderItemProcessingStatus.Processing2
member.summary: Order item cooking was started, cooking is in second step progress.

member.name: F:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.KitchenOrderItemProcessingStatus.Processing3
member.summary: Order item cooking was started, cooking is in third step progress.

member.name: F:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.KitchenOrderItemProcessingStatus.Processing4
member.summary: Order item cooking was started, cooking is in fourth step progress.

member.name: F:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.KitchenOrderItemProcessingStatus.Processed
member.summary: Order item cooking completed, dish is ready to be served.

member.name: F:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.KitchenOrderItemProcessingStatus.Served
member.summary: Order item was cooked and served.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrder
member.summary: Order equivalent for kitchen. Kitchen orders created automatically from and have independent lifetime.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrder.Number
member.summary: Number of the source order.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrder.Table
member.summary: Table of the source order.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrder.Waiter
member.summary: Person who serves the source order.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrder.Items
member.summary: Source order item products equivalent for kitchen. Only printed order item products are taken into account for kitchen.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrder.BaseOrderId
member.summary: Base order id.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrder.IsTopCookingPriority
member.summary: The flag specifies that this order should be cooked out-of-order at kitchen. All orders which have this flag set on will appear above other orders at the kitchen display. Both groups (top priority and non-top priority) will be sorted separately using usual sorting logic (custom cooking priority, then default built-in criterions. Default value is false.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrder.CookingPriority
member.summary: Specifies a custom cooking priority. While the application provides built-in prioritization logic for orders based on timing, dish courses, etc., you can override it and enforce custom cooking order based on your external logic. Ideally, all dishes should be cooked timely, but in case of concurrency when kitchen is high-loaded, you have to decide which orders are more important and should be cooked in the first place and which orders are allowed to be delayed. Higher priority values mean that the order, its serve groups and dishes will appear at the kitchen display earlier. Default value is zero. Both positive and negative values are allowed for raising and lowering the priority correspondingly. Orders with the same cooking priority will be sorted using default built-in logic.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrderCookingItem
member.summary: Order cooking item equivalent for kitchen.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrderCookingItem.Course
member.summary: Gets course of this kitchen order item.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrderCookingItem.IsCookingStarted
member.summary: Whether cooking of the item started. Depending on kitchen settings and waiter intentions item cooking can start immediately after printing or with some delay. Item with short cooking time may wait for long-time cooking item from the same serve group (to be served together), item of second or above course may wait for corresponding serve cheque printing. This property is perfect, expected state, do not mess up with processing status, which means actual status (cook can begin processing before or after the appointed time).

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrderCookingItem.PrintTime
member.summary: Source order item print time.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrderCookingItem.EstimatedCookingBeginTime
member.summary: Moment when item cooking should be started. This property is null until cooking should be started.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Data.Kitchen.IKitchenOrderItemModifier.IsSeparate
member.summary: Whether modifier should be cooked separately from its product. In general this property exposes modifier semantics: while some modifiers specify how to cook their product, another modifiers are additional dish parts or even separate dishes. First type completely depends on product and has the same cooking property values, second type is separate and has own kitchen, status etc.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Attributes.JetBrains.NotifyPropertyChangedInvocatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the method is contained in a type that implements System.ComponentModel.INotifyPropertyChanged interface and this method is used to notify that some property value changed.
member.remarks:
The method should be non-static and conform to one of the supported signatures:
NotifyChanged(string)
NotifyChanged(params string[])
NotifyChanged{T}(Expression{Func{T}})
NotifyChanged{T,U}(Expression{Func{T,U}})
SetProperty{T}(ref T, T, string)

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Attributes.JetBrains.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output.
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for method output means that the methos doesn't return normally (throws or terminates the process).
Value canbenull is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon. There is no notion of order rows, all rows are checked for applicability and applied per each program state tracked by R# analysis.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // regular assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // string.IsNullOrEmpty()
[ContractAnnotation("=> true, result: notnull; => false, result: null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Attributes.JetBrains.SourceTemplateAttribute
member.summary: An extension method marked with this attribute is processed by ReSharper code completion as a 'Source Template'. When extension method is completed over some expression, it's source code is automatically expanded like a template at call site.
member.remarks: Template method body can contain valid source code and/or special comments starting with '$'. Text inside these comments is added as source code when the template is applied. Template parameters can be used either as additional method parameters or as identifiers wrapped in two '$' signs. Use the attribute to specify macros for parameters.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Attributes.JetBrains.MacroAttribute
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro for a parameter of a source template.
member.remarks: You can apply the attribute on the whole method or on any of its additional parameters. The macro expression is defined in the property. When applied on a method, the target template parameter is defined in the property. To apply the macro silently for the parameter, set the property value = -1.

member.name: P:Resto.Front.Api.Attributes.JetBrains.MacroAttribute.Expression
member.summary: Allows specifying a macro that will be executed for a source template parameter when the template is expanded.

members.member:
Allows specifying which occurrence of the target parameter becomes editable when the template is deployed.
If the target parameter is used several times in the template, only one occurrence becomes editable; other occurrences are changed synchronously. To specify the zero-based index of the editable occurrence, use values >= 0. To make the parameter non-editable when the template is expanded, use -1. >

member.summary: XAML attribute. Indicates the type that has ItemsSource property and should be treated as ItemsControl-derived type, to enable inner items DataContext type resolve.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Attributes.JetBrains.XamlItemBindingOfItemsControlAttribute
member.summary: XAML attribute. Indicates the property of some BindingBase-derived type, that is used to bind some item of ItemsControl-derived type. This annotation will enable the DataContext type resolve for XAML bindings for such properties.
member.remarks: Property should have the tree ancestor of the ItemsControl type or marked with the attribute.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.Attributes.PluginLicenseModuleIdAttribute
member.summary: Specifies plugin's licensable module identifier.
member.remarks:
If plugin is intended to be distributed by license per plugin scheme, contact iiko to register licensable module for your plugin, then apply this attribute to plugin with received module identifier.
Each plugin instance will require another one license slot, so total slots number for given license module should correspond to count of simultaneously running iikoFronts with your plugin installed to.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The licensable module identifier.

member.param: Amount of the modifier. Can be from 1 to 999.
Predefined fixed price of the modifier, allows to use external quotation instead of default price list. null means default price.
Assortment position for modifier. Must be accessible through IOrderProductItem.AvailableSimpleModifiers collection or one of the IOrderProductItem.AvailableGroupModifiers child collections.

Assortment position group for modifier. Must be specified if new modifier will be part of the group modifier. Otherwise null. Group modifier must be chosen from IOrderProductItem.AvailableGroupModifiers
Order to which modifier will be added
Order item to which modifier will be added.

member.name: M:Resto.Front.Api.Extensions.OperationServiceExtensions.RegisterExternalOperation``2(Resto.Front.Api.IOperationService,System.String,System.String,System.Func{``0,``1},System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationBinder,System.Runtime.Serialization.ISurrogateSelector)
member.summary: Exposes a custom operation to be available for call by other plugins. The registration is not permanent, it holds true until disposing the return value, or plugin shutdown.
member.remarks: Different plugins running under the same iikoFront application instance can communicate via external operations. iikoFront just transfers requests and responses between plugins without knowing any details. Both producer and consumer plugins should understand the data structure, developers should negotiate a protocol specification, pre-share operation names, handle versioning and so on. Producer plugin registers an operation using and consumer plugin call it using .
member.param: Operation service.

Identifies the external service, just a namespace for a set of interrelated operations, which helps to group them logically. It's recommended to choose a unique name to avoid collisions with other plugins, i.e. include company's name or plugin's name into the service name. Min length is 1, max length is 50 chars.

In aggregate with identifies the operation. Both names have to be pre-shared with consumer plugins, so that they will be able to call the operation referring it by service and operation name. The combination of a service name and operation name must be unique at the same time. Min length is 1, max length is 50 chars.
The operation implementation, which will be called by other plugins via .
A serialization binder for custom mapping between types and names. Default is null.
The to use for serialization. Default is null.

member.name: M:Resto.Front.Api.Extensions.OperationServiceExtensions.CallExternalOperation``2(Resto.Front.Api.IOperationService,System.String,System.String,``0,System.Runtime.Serialization.SerializationBinder,System.Runtime.Serialization.ISurrogateSelector)
member.summary: Calls an operation which is implemented in another plugin.
member.remarks: Different plugins running under the same iikoFront application instance can communicate via external operations. iikoFront just transfers requests and responses between plugins without knowing any details. Both producer and consumer plugins should understand the data structure, developers should negotiate a protocol specification, pre-share operation names, handle versioning and so on. Producer plugin registers an operation using and consumer plugin call it using .
member.param: Operation service.
Name of the external service which is implemented in another plugin. That name have to be pre-shared with consumer plugins.
Name of the external operation which is implemented in another plugin and have been registered using . That name have to be pre-shared between producer and consumer plugins.
The data which will be transferred as an incoming argument into the external operation.
A serialization binder for custom mapping between types and names. Default is null.
The to use for serialization. Default is null.
member.returns: Response returned by the producer plugin.
member.exception: When an external operation throws any kind of exception, callee receives the with original message. Orignal stacktrace can be found in api.log.

member.name: M:Resto.Front.Api.Extensions.OperationServiceExtensions.ExecuteContinuousOperation(Resto.Front.Api.IOperationService,System.Action{Resto.Front.Api.IOperationService})
member.summary: Executes the callback function as one continuous operation by providing temporary instance of , which holds internal locks taken on lockable entities (such as order) until the operation ends. It's strongly recommended to avoid potentially obstructive calls in the callback, i.e network calls, heavy I/O or CPU-bound calls, thread blocking and so on, because touched entities will remain locked for a long time.
member.remarks: It could be useful for calling several methods of the local instance sequentially when it's important to call them one by one without outside changes. While all committed changes will immediately become visible for everyone, no one except of the provided callback will be allowed to alter entities which were touched via that short-living (input argument of the callback). For example, you can create a new order and add there guests, products and external prepay using one edit session, but you cannot print order items or process external prepay in the same session, because these operations can't be rolled back and thus aren't available via . Executing these operations separately on a global isn't reliable because there is a chance to be interrupted by a user, other plugin or background entity change handlers, which may prevent further our edits by applying conflicting changes or by locking an entity for a long time.
member.param: Operation service.
Callback to be executed continuously.

member.name: M:Resto.Front.Api.Extensions.OperationServiceExtensions.ExecuteContinuousOperation``1(Resto.Front.Api.IOperationService,System.Func{Resto.Front.Api.IOperationService,``0})

member.remarks: It could be useful for calling several methods of the local instance sequentially when it's important to call them one by one without outside changes. While all committed changes will immediately become visible for everyone, no one except of the provided callback will be allowed to alter entities which were touched via that short-living (input argument of the callback). For example, you can create a new order and add there guests, products and external prepay using one edit session, but you cannot print order items or process external prepay in the same session, because these operations can't be rolled back and thus aren't available via . Executing these operations separately on a global isn't reliable because there is a chance to be interrupted by a user, other plugin or background entity change handlers, which may prevent further our edits by applying conflicting changes or by locking an entity for a long time.

member.name: T:Resto.Front.Api.PluginContext
member.summary: Provides access to api services.

member.name: M:Resto.Front.Api.PluginContext.Initialize(System.IServiceProvider,System.Action,Resto.Front.Api.ILog)
member.summary: Fills the context with Api services on plugin startup. This method isn't intended to be called from plugin.
member.remarks: Primarily this method is used by Api infrastructure, but it also can be used in unit tests for checking plugin's code. When writing tests against code which is using static properties of , you can initialize the context with dummy (mocked) services. Services are retrieved from the provider when corresponding static properties are called, so for testing purposes you may provide minimum set of services which are actually used in the code being tested.

member.name: M:Resto.Front.Api.PluginContext.Uninitialize
member.summary: Resets the context to uninitialized state. This method isn't intended to be called from plugin.
member.remarks: Use this method in unit tests to reset the context and re-initialize with appropriate services for each test fixture.

member.name: M:Resto.Front.Api.IOperationService.RegisterExternalOperation(System.String,System.String,Resto.Front.Api.RemotingHelpers.RemotableFunc{System.Byte[],System.Byte[]})
member.summary: Exposes a custom operation to be available for call by other plugins. The registration is not permanent, it holds true until disposing the return value, or plugin shutdown.
member.remarks: Different plugins running under the same iikoFront application instance can communicate via external operations. iikoFront just transfers requests and responses between plugins without knowing any details. Both producer and consumer plugins should understand the data structure, developers should negotiate a protocol specification, pre-share operation names, handle versioning and so on. Producer plugin registers an operation using and consumer plugin call it using .
member.param: Identifies the external service, just a namespace for a set of interrelated operations, which helps to group them logically. It's recommended to choose a unique name to avoid collisions with other plugins, i.e. include company's name or plugin's name into the service name. Min length is 1, max length is 50 chars.

In aggregate with identifies the operation. Both names have to be pre-shared with consumer plugins, so that they will be able to call the operation referring it by service and operation name. The combination of a service name and operation name must be unique at the same time. Min length is 1, max length is 50 chars.
The operation implementation, which will be called by other plugins via .

member.name: M:Resto.Front.Api.IOperationService.CallExternalOperation(System.String,System.String,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Calls an operation which is implemented in another plugin.
member.remarks: Different plugins running under the same iikoFront application instance can communicate via external operations. iikoFront just transfers requests and responses between plugins without knowing any details. Both producer and consumer plugins should understand the data structure, developers should negotiate a protocol specification, pre-share operation names, handle versioning and so on. Producer plugin registers an operation using and consumer plugin call it using .
member.param: Name of the external service which is implemented in another plugin. That name have to be pre-shared with consumer plugins.
Name of the external operation which is implemented in another plugin and have been registered using . That name have to be pre-shared between producer and consumer plugins.
The data which will be transferred as an incoming argument into the external operation.
member.returns: Response returned by the producer plugin.
member.exception: When an external operation throws any kind of exception, caller receives the with original message. Orignal stacktrace can be found in api.log.

member.summary: Returns currently registered external operations grouped by service name.

member.name: M:Resto.Front.Api.IOperationService.ExecuteContinuousOperation(Resto.Front.Api.RemotingHelpers.RemotableAction{Resto.Front.Api.IOperationService})
member.summary: Executes the callback function as one continuous operation by providing temporary instance of , which holds internal locks taken on lockable entities (such as order) until the operation ends. It's strongly recommended to avoid potentially obstructive calls in the callback, i.e network calls, heavy I/O or CPU-bound calls, thread blocking and so on, because touched entities will remain locked for a long time.
member.remarks: It could be useful for calling several methods of the local instance sequentially when it's important to call them one by one without outside changes. While all committed changes will immediately become visible for everyone, no one except of the provided callback will be allowed to alter entities which were touched via that short-living (input argument of the callback). For example, you can create a new order and add there guests, products and external prepay using one edit session, but you cannot print order items or process external prepay in the same session, because these operations can't be rolled back and thus aren't available via . Executing these operations separately on a global isn't reliable because there is a chance to be interrupted by a user, other plugin or background entity change handlers, which may prevent further our edits by applying conflicting changes or by locking an entity for a long time.
member.param: Callback to be executed continuously.

member.name: M:Resto.Front.Api.IOperationService.GetOrganizationFingerprint
member.summary: Returns a fingerprint which can be used to identify an iikoRMS server instance.
member.remarks: Sometimes iikoRMS server instances are being cloned with entire database, so that all their key entities have duplicated ids. Fingerprints help to detect changes of some specific server instance properties, which are usually different for cloned instances, but sometimes also may change on the same instance without any cloning. It is assumed that the plugin compares the currently received fingerprint with previously remembered one to ensure that it communicates with the same iikoRMS server instance. Fingerprints equality means that there is the same server instance. When fingerprints are different, plugin should somehow check, whether it is another instance or the fingerprint of the original instance has been changed. The method requires a connection to the iikoRMS server, so calling this method in offline mode will end up with an exception.
member.exception: Underlying network request to the iikoRMS server has failed.
